6T15-5.1_4.2_4.2.features: Real and imaginary quadratic number fields
6T15-5.1_4.2_4.2.flavor: These dessins correspond to Belyi maps from elliptic curves to the Riemann sphere.
6T15-5.1_4.2_4.2.trivia: The elliptic curves in this puzzle are defined over the number fields \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-15})\) and \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{15})\). The curve from orbit A is defined over \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-15})\) and has conductor norm 11520, while the curve from orbit B, which has LMFDB label 2.2.60.1-90.1-a3, is defined over \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{15})\) and has conductor norm 90.

6T15-5.1_5.1_4.2.flavor: These dessins correspond to Belyi maps from elliptic curves to the Riemann sphere.
6T15-5.1_5.1_4.2.trivia: The elliptic curve in orbit A is defined over the biquadratic field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-6}, \sqrt{10})\) and has conductor norm 40500, while the curve from orbit B is defined over a \(D_4\) number field and has conductor norm 36.

6T16-5.1_3.2.1_3.2.1.flavor: Just as in the first puzzle, one of the maps stands alone and is defined over the rational numbers, while the other six are related by Galois symmetries.
6T16-5.1_3.2.1_3.2.1.trivia: The six related maps are defined over the degree 6 number field with defining polynomial \(t^{6} + 3 t^{4} - 10 t^{3} + 3 t^{2} + 1\).

6T16-6_6_5.1.flavor: These dessins correspond to Belyi maps defined on genus 2 hyperelliptic curves. Just as in the first puzzle, one of the maps stands alone and is defined over the rational numbers, while the other six are related by Galois symmetries.

7T5-7_7_3.3.1.flavor: These dessins correspond to Belyi maps defined on genus 2 hyperelliptic curves.
7T5-7_7_3.3.1.trivia: Both Belyi map orbits are defined over the number field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-7})\).

7T6-4.2.1_4.2.1_3.2.2.trivia: This passport consists of one orbit of size 2, defined over the field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{7})\), and one of size 4, defined over a \(D_4\) number field.

7T6-5.1.1_3.2.2_5.1.1.trivia: This passport consists of two orbits of size 2, one defined over the real quadratic field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})\), and the other defined over the imaginary quadratic field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})\).

7T6-5.1.1_4.2.1_3.2.2.flavor: This is the puzzle from the introduction.
7T6-5.1.1_4.2.1_3.2.2.trivia: The Belyi map in orbit A stands alone because we can describe it with rational numbers, which have no symmetries besides the identity. To describe the maps in orbit B, we also need a root of the polynomial \(x^3 - x^2 + 2x - 38\). These three maps are related by the symmetries that exchange the roots of the polynomial.

7T6-7_4.2.1_3.2.2.flavor: The Belyi maps corresponding to these dessins are defined on elliptic curves.
7T6-7_4.2.1_3.2.2.trivia: The Belyi maps in the Galois orbit of size 2 is defined on an elliptic curve over the real quadratic field \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{70})\) with conductor norm 13230. The maps in the orbit of size 6 are defined on an elliptic curve with conductor norm 882000.

7T6-7_4.2.1_4.2.1.trivia: The maps in the orbit of size 2 are defined on an elliptic curve over \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{21})\) with conductor norm 2822400.

7T6-7_5.1.1_3.2.2.flavor: Just as in the first puzzle, one of the maps stands alone and is defined over the rational numbers, while the other six are related by Galois symmetries.
7T6-7_5.1.1_3.2.2.trivia: The map in the Galois orbit of size 1 is defined on the elliptic curve with LMFDB label 7350.ck1.

7T6-7_7_2.2.1.1.1.trivia: The map in the Galois orbit of size 1 is defined on the elliptic curve with LMFDB label 490.e2. The maps in the orbit of size 2 are defined on an elliptic curve over \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{21})\) with conductor norm 2940.

7T6-7_7_3.1.1.1.1.flavor: These pictures each describe a Belyi map from a torus to a sphere. The torus has a different “elliptic curve” structure in each orbit. One of the elliptic curves has an unusually small conductor. Can you guess which orbit it belongs to?
7T6-7_7_3.1.1.1.1.trivia: The elliptic curve with a small conductor belongs to orbit A.

7T6-7_7_3.2.2.trivia: This passport decomposes into four orbits defined over \(\mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{21}), \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{7})\), and \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-1})\), respectively. The map in the orbit of size 1 is defined on a genus 2 curve with conductor 129654.

7T6-7_7_3.3.1.trivia: This passport decomposes into 3 orbits defined over \(\mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})\), and a quintic number field, respectively. The map in the orbit of size 1 is defined on a genus 2 curve with conductor 1555848.
